title: How to Compress Image Online For Free?
author: Karan Singh Manral

data.children: In today's digital age, images are a crucial part of our online and offline experiences. Whether you're a photographer, a web developer, or simply someone who likes to share photos on social media, dealing with large image files can be a common challenge. Large images not only take up valuable storage space but can also slow down websites and affect user experiences. To address this issue, image compression is a valuable technique that can help reduce the file size of images without compromising their quality. In this comprehensive guide, we will explore various methods and tools for compressing images efficiently.
Understanding Image Compression
Before we dive into the techniques for image compression, it's essential to understand what image compression is and why it's necessary.
What Is Image Compression?

The process of reducing the size of an image is called image compression. The primary goal is to make images more manageable in terms of storage, transmission, and loading times. Compression achieves this by eliminating or reducing redundant data in the image file.
Why Is Image Compression Important?

children.children: Compressed images occupy less storage space, making it easier to manage and share them.
Smaller image files load more quickly on websites and apps, improving user experiences.
Compressed images consume less bandwidth when transmitted over the internet, saving data costs.
Faster-loading web pages with smaller images tend to rank higher in search engine results.
Users are more likely to engage with websites and content that load quickly and smoothly.

data.children: Now that we understand the importance of image compression, let's explore various methods to achieve it.
Methods of Image Compression
Two types of image compression techniques are lossy and lossless compression. Both have some marvels and limitations and is suitable for different purposes.
Lossy Compression

In Lossy compression the file size of an image is reduced by removing some of its data. While this results in a smaller file size, it also leads to a minor loss of image quality, especially when heavily compressed. Common lossy compression formats include JPEG and WebP. Here's how to use lossy compression.
Lossless Compression

In Lossless compression the file size of an image is reduced without losing its quality. When you compress an image using lossless methods, you can later decompress it to its original form without any loss of data or quality. PNG and GIF are some common lossless compression formats.
Now you also want to make your website more appealing and attractive by using high-quality images?

The main issue arises with size of those beautiful images which is so large to damage your website's loading speed. But now you don't need to worry about the size of images because there are several tools to solve this problem.
In this article you will come across several image optimization tools.So let's begin.
1. iLoveIMG
Born and based in Barcelona, since 2016 iLoveIMG offers simple and smooth image editing tools that load fast and get the job done.

Now, you can easily modify images in bulk, fast! The tools have everything you need to compress, crop, convert, and resize images all in one place. You can even make animated GIFs with just a few clicks, and it's all free.
2. Compress Image - Try Web Soft
Compress Image is a online web based image compressor that compresses multiple images at a time.

It is a pure javascript based tool that doesn't use any server which make it safer than any other image compressor online. It is a free to use software where you can compress your images quickly at no cost.
3. TinyPNG

Tiny PNG is an online image compression business. Its compression algorithm facilitates fantastic performance by reducing image sizes without adversely affecting their quality from a visual perspective. As the name suggests, it works on PNG file types.

But in terms of compressing any image, it will also compress JPEG images. The free version restricts the file size to a maximum of 5mb. If an image is much larger than this, then it will still be too big for your website. You can upload up to 20 images at once and up to 100 images in a month. The size for each image should be up to 5 MB.

Using the TinyPNG compression tool is easy. Users just have to drag and drop the files, and in just a few seconds, depending on the size of the image, after clicking to download the files separately or all together in zipping to save them to Dropbox.
4. Kraken
Kraken is one of the most reliable image optimization tools out there. It has 3 main modes of compression; Lossless, Lossy and Expert, with different optimization algorithms operating accordingly.

The Lossy optimization mode definitely serves most users' requirements. Its results are 60-80% smaller file sizes compared to the original. This algorithm produces images that are of good quality as compared to the original.

For a photographer or a professional that needs to work with images of the highest quality, then Lossless mode is the best choice. This offers no reduction in the quality of the compressed image. This mode does not affect the pixel quality. This is suitable for situations that have high-quality requirements for visuals, such as marketing graphics.

The Expert view provides users with more detailed tweaks and is designed for users already familiar with image processing and optimization processes. This facilitates different quality levels for lossy JPEG and PNG optimization, preserves certain entries in the EXIF metadata, and automatically modifies image orientation.
5. Optimizilla

Optimizilla is just like TinyPNG, which supports JPEG and PNG formats. It provides a good quality/size ratio as it combines great optimization and lossy compression algorithms to attain the minimum possible size whilst maintaining the quality level.
Conclusion

Image compression is a valuable technique for reducing file sizes while maintaining acceptable image quality. Whether you're managing a website, sharing images on social media, or storing a collection of photos, understanding how to compress images effectively can significantly improve your online and offline experiences. By choosing the right compression methods and following best practices, you can strike the perfect balance between image quality and file size.
